fields.essay:
Crystal Cove State Park’s historic district includes 46 beach cottages built during the 1930s that serve as a classic example of early Southern Californian development. The cottages were originally built on land owned by James Irvine. The Irvine Company, a realty company owned by Irvine, offered permanent leases to the residents living there, with the stipulation that they could not make any renovations to the cottages. This helped to keep the cottages looking just as they did in the 1930s.

Information Source: California Department of Parks and Recreation, 2016. Crystal Cove State Park.

Crystal Cove State Park is located near Corona Del Mar and Laguna Beach in Orange County. It comprises 2,791 acres, which include chaparral canyons, a 12.3 strip of coastline, and a historic district.

The park offers a quintessential example of the chaparral beach and canyon environment that can only be found in Southern California. The chaparral biome is a dry shrubland with a Mediterranean-type climate. The Crystal Cove canyons are home to an impressive 180 species of birds and 26 species of reptiles in what is a relatively small area. All of these animals have adapted to the unique chaparral environment. If Crystal Cove were not protected as a state park, many of these species would not be able to survive in other habitats because of their specific adaptations to the Southern California landscape.

Crystal Cove became a state park in 1982, with the help of local activists like Christine Shirley. Shirley lived in one of the 46 beach cottages that line the beach, and when the Irvine Company tried to sell the land to a developer that would demolish the cottages, she teamed up with fellow Crystal Cove residents to get the area added to the National Register of Historic Places.Thanks to her work, the cottages are now preserved as a part of the Crystal Cove Historic District, and can be viewed by visitors today.

Information Source: Crystal Cove State Park, 2016. History of the Area.

Tide pools are clustered around the coast of Crystal Cove and its adjacent beaches. The tide pools serve as a habitat for 36 different marine organisms, many of which can only be found on the coast of Southern California. These include the Ochre Star and California Mussel, which are keystone species that have a large effect on the other organisms living in a habitat.

Information Source: California Department of Parks and Recreation, 2016. Crystal Cove State Park.

This artist book, created by Barbara Milman, is a response to an oil spill near her hometown of San Francisco. As shown in the book, and oil ship spilled 58,000 gallons of fuel oil near the Golden Gate Bridge, resulting in the closing of more than 50 public beaches, the covering of 200 miles of coastline in oil, and the death of more than 6,000 birds. Although this spill did not occur in Southern California, the event and the artist’s consequent reaction is a grim reminder of the potential dangers that oil rigs and ships pose to marine and coastal life in the state writ large. By bringing awareness of the results of a particular oil spill, the author hopes to further interest public in this important environmental issue.

Information Source: NBC News, 20 May 2015. 1969 Oil Spill Near Santa Barbara...

This image and the next show oil rigs in Southern California’s coastal cities. There are around 27 oil and gas rigs in Southern California, all of which pose the threat of a spill and therefore a danger to the special chaparral beach environment and the 200 unique species that live Southern Californian waters. One of the most recent oil spills in Southern California happened in Ventura, where 29,400 gallons of oil were spilled into the ocean.

Information Source: California Coastal Commission, 2016. Oil Spill Program.

This image shows an oil rig located in Huntington Beach. Oil spills affect both marine and coastal species. When tar and oil from the rigs wash up on the beaches, they can negatively impact the health of the organisms that live there. When animals are coated in oil they may obtain hyperthermia or lose mobility, and when they ingest it they may suffer poisoning and internal damage. The population as a whole may decrease due to damage to eggs. Meanwhile, oil can generally deteriorate the marine habitat by killing plankton and algae -- two organisms that work to keep the whole habitat balanced.

Littering is also a common and continual environmental problem in Southern California’s beach cities. Many cities coordinate volunteer efforts by citizens and companies to help clean up the litter on the beach, as this historical image illustrates. Although preventative action--that is, stopping littering before it happens -- is best, efforts like these are productive. By reducing litter, the cities not only prevent harm to coastal environments, but also keep the beaches looking clean, attract more visitors, and therefore generate more revenue.

Information Source: State of California Ocean Protective Council, 2016. Preventing Ocean Litter.

Southern California has some of the largest harbors and ports in the United States, including the Port of Los Angeles. Many cargo ships come through these ports, which unfortunately pollutes the harbors with fossil fuels and air pollution.

However, the general composition of ocean litter is predominantly plastic. The pollution often drifts into the ocean, where it is called marine debris and can collect in large masses. For example, the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, in the Northern Pacific Ocean, contains a huge amount of plastics, sludge, and other litter that has been collected and trapped by ocean currents.

When plastics and other non-biodegradable materials enter the ocean, sea creatures eat them and often die; invasive species attach to them and float to new habitats; and even humans can end up ingesting toxic waste by way of eating fish that have consumed it.

Information Source: State of California Ocean Protective Council, 2008. An Implementation Strategy for the California Ocean Protection...

Southern California is also home to the Mojave Desert, which is the largest desert in North America and contains thousands of species of plants and animals. Among these is the Joshua tree, which only grows in the Mojave Desert at an elevation of 1,300 - 5,900 feet. Scientists estimate that Joshua Trees will be nearly extinct by the end of the 21st century, due in large part to the extinction of the Giant Shasta Ground Sloth 4,400 years ago. Ground Sloths helped spread Joshua Tree seeds through their waste. The Mojave Desert is also the site of Death Valley, which has the hottest recorded temperature found anywhere in the world.

Information Source: National Parks Service, 2016. Mojave Administrative History.

Public interest in the Mojave began in the years after World War II, when many soldiers who had been stationed there wanted to return and visit the desert with their families. Unfortunately, visitors to the region began holding off-roading races, which were detrimental to the vegetation and wildlife of the desert. This type of damaging activity has been curtailed in recent decades, especially since the Mojave Desert became a National Park in 1994 with the passage of the California Desert Protection Act.

Information Source: National Parks Service, 2016. Mojave Administrative History.

Elden Hughes was an activist who led a large campaign to pass the Desert Protection Act. Hughes was known to walk into congressional offices with a dozen baby tortoises to lobby for the preservation of their home, the Mojave. He helped raise the $45 million dollars needed to purchase the land encompassing the Mojave Desert in order to turn it into a National Park.

Information Source: Sierra Club, 12 February 2016. California Desert National Monuments...

The Pleasants Family lived in Southern California during the 1860’s, and through their writings show what life was like during that time period.This document from the Pleasants Family Papers details J.E. Pleasants’s experience herding cattle in the Mojave during a drought. Reading the manuscript, one can practically feel the hot and arid weather of the desert. Pleasants notes that it was “probably the worst drought in the history of California”, and “this wind would blow for days, parching the already dry ground.” These comments carry forebodings of the drought and water conservation challenges that Southern California currently faces.

There are several species of cactus that are special to the Mojave Desert, including the Barrel, Hedgehog, Pincushion, Beavertail Pricklypear, and Cholla cacti. The Beavertail Pricklypear can be found all throughout the Mojave Desert, and blooms a beautiful magenta flower in the spring and early summer.

Information Source: National Parks Service, 2016. Cacti/Desert Succulents.

Southern California is home to four national forests: the Angeles, San Bernardino, Cleveland, and Los Padres. The forests are mountainous, contain dry shrubs, and will periodically burn in mild fires. These mild fires allow for regrowth of plants and distribution of seeds.

This document describes the differences in plant life in Southern California forests as the elevation increases. The author, Adelina Pleasants, talks about “characteristic” plant species that are found in the mountains’ forest. One is the knob-cone pine, which needs a forest fire to release its seeds so new trees can grow. Forest fires are typical of the relatively dry Southern Californian climate, and this species of tree has adapted to fit the particular conditions of the mountains found there.

Information Source: Center for Biological Diversity, 2016. Southern California Forests.

Don Meadows, a local Orange County historian, documented many aspects of Orange County life and nature. He worked as a Park Naturalist at the Big Basin Redwoods and Calaveras Big Trees State Parks during the 1960’s. His work documenting wildlife and historical districts helped to educate many about the natural and historical aspects of Southern California.

Information Source: Online Archive of California, 2016. Guide to the Don Meadows Papers.
This document lists 28 trees native to Orange County. There are many additional species native to the forests of the Southern California region as a whole.

J.E. Pleasants and his family documented many areas in California, including the vegetation, wildlife, and personal experiences of the Southern Californian mountains. Thanks to his documentation, the public can learn how many different types of plant species were found throughout the different regions of Southern California during the time of Pleasants.

Information Source: Online Archive of California, 2016. Guide to the Pleasants Family Papers.

Deforestation is a very real threat to the mountains and forests of California. In 2006, total profits from California’s lumber industry amounted to $1.5 billion. The United States Forest Service acts to monitor and regulate the lumber industry to ensure they operate sustainably and do not harm the forest habitats.

Information Source: United States Department of Agriculture, August 2012. California’s Forest Products Industry and Timber Harvest

Deforestation especially an issue in California because of the need to clear land for more urban development. Southern California has a high population density, with around 22 million people living in the area, nearly 60 percent of the state of California’s population. The image here shows another example of deforestation in Southern California, this time in Laguna Beach, potentially to make room for more development near the popular beach city.

Information Source: California Energy Commission, March 2013. Deforestation in California...

Wildfires are a common occurrence in Southern California. Wildfire prevention became especially important during World War II, when American men were drafted into the war effort and could not fight fires on the homefront. The government began a campaign to ask the public to help prevent forest fires, and they needed a symbol. Smokey Bear was a bear cub rescued from a forest fire in 1950. He became “Smokey the Bear,” a symbol for forest fire prevention, and has remained so today.

Information Source: Smokey the Bear, 2016. Smokey's Story

This large color pen and pencil artwork by Trinh Do illustrates three stages of the Southeast Asian refugee experience: homeland, escape, and refugee camp. The artwork is divided into three horizontal panels, moving from top to bottom. 

The top panel depicts scenes of Vietnam from a bucolic rural past to a postwar Vietnam under communist rule, which includes scenes of "reeducation camps," the official name of prison camps operated by the new Vietnam communist regime after it took power in 1975. These camps were places where South Vietnamese were sent for ideological re-training. 

The middle panel highlights the dangerous journeys undertaken by “boat people” refugees from the late 1970s to the 1990s. (“Boat people” was a term used by the news media and in government and scholarly publications to refer to people who escaped their country by boat following the Vietnam War. )

The bottom panel shows aspects of the refugee camp experience including the closed camps policed by armed guards. It offers the viewer a glimpse into the community life constructed by refugees under harsh circumstances. 

Considered a “dissident artist,” Trinh Do was imprisoned in Vietnam. After escaping from prison, he, his wife, and their ten-year-old son came to Hong Kong's Whitehead Detention Center in 1989. Trinh Do served as the editor-in-chief of _Tự Do_ (Vietnamese for _Freedom_), a monthly newsletter published in Whitehead for the Vietnamese population.

_Embarquement pour la liberté_ expresses a refugee’s melancholy upon leaving his/her homeland for an uncertain future. A tiny diagonal line of people draws our attention to the small boat that they are relying on to take them to safety. The boat looks small compared to the vast and seemingly endless ocean that lies ahead of it. The boats that carried people away from Vietnam were often unseaworthy, lacking in adequate supplies, and severely overcrowded. It is estimated that as many as a third of the “boat people” died at sea.

“Then and there the war was over! The Communists were coming! Death and jailing was spreading in my country!” This letter, written to the homeland by a refugee who was resettled in the United States, appeals to the homeland to “survive” and reinforces a commitment to return.

Nguyen Tien Ngoc’s _Unreachable Trip_ captures the chaotic and agonizing journey endured by the people who fled Southeast Asia during the Vietnam War in search of asylum in Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia, and other nearby countries. 

The landmass in the foreground of the painting is inscribed with words: “HK” (for Hong Kong), “Indonesia,” “Malaysia,” and “boat people.” These words refer to the displaced people and the destinations they seek to reach. The refugee’s desire to acquire sanctuary in a new homeland is suggested by the use of similar colors to tie the figure to the land.

This statistical report, published by the United States Office of Refugee Resettlement, shows figures from 1981. The Office was established by the 1980 Refugee Act passed under the Carter Administration.

Countries that received the largest populations of boat refugees were Malaysia, Hong Kong and Thailand. The camps within these countries were often referred to as “first asylum camps” since this is where refugees initially arrived and were processed for potential resettlement. Meanwhile, land refugees--mostly Cambodian (Khmer) people who fled their homeland by foot--gathered mainly in Thailand.

Tran Mai Hanh explores themes of life and death, risk and hope in _On Liberty (Le Sinistre Moissonneur)_. The French subtitle translates to _The Grim Reaper_. 

The rower could be seen to represent the hundreds of thousands of refugees fleeing their countries after the end of the Vietnam War. Due to their opposition to the new Vietnamese regime, these people tried to escape to a place they could call home. The work illustrates how many Southeast Asian refugees would rather risk their lives than betray their values. Holding on to what they had left—their bodies, families, valuable belongings, and religious beliefs—these refugees did everything possible to find a better life. Even if it meant undergoing the risks of traveling through sea storms, suffering from starvation, and facing pirates, they refused to surrender to the new Vietnamese regime.

Nguyen Dai Giang created _Tự Do hay là Chết_ (_Freedom or Death_), a gouache on paper painting, in 1990. An artist from Hanoi, Vietnam, he arrived in Pillar Point Open Camp in Hong Kong in 1988 after seven years spent in a Vietnamese prison. As a refugee in this camp, he was commissioned by the Housing Department to create several wall murals. Many of his other artworks have been collected and preserved in the UC Irvine Southeast Asian Archive’s Project Ngoc Records.

“Freedom or death” is a mantra repeated throughout various types of materials represented in the Southeast Asian Archive, including art, poetry, correspondence, and news clippings.

After the 1979 Geneva Conference, the numbers of Southeast Asian refugees arriving in first asylum countries greatly exceeded the numbers of those accepted for resettlement. As a result, Hong Kong issued a “closed camp policy” in 1982, which confined refugees to the guarded and barbed- wire boundaries of their camps. 

Many refugee artworks in the UC Irvine Southeast Asian Archive collections do not have information on the artists. One reason for this anonymity may be that some artists feared persecution.

Some paintings, however, include an identification number along with the artist signature. When a person arrived in a refugee camp, he or she was assigned some form of documentation for identity and travel purposes by the camp authorities. An identification number does not necessarily indicate refugee status or resettlement status. It was a means through which local authorities could fulfill the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) mandate to provide asylum-seekers with identity documents.

The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) reports that between 1975 and 1997, about 839,000 refugees arrived by boat to refugee camps in Southeast Asia. The international definition of “refugee” was established by the 1951 United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and was applied as the standard for screening processes. A refugee is defined as someone outside “the country of his former habitual residence because he has or had well-grounded fear of persecution by reason of his race, religion, nationality or political opinion.”

Due to the continued arrivals of refugees, these Southeast Asian governments confronted overcrowding in the camps and a resettlement bottleneck. They turned to repatriation as a solution. Of the 839,000 people who arrived, over 109,000 were sent back to Vietnam either voluntarily or involuntarily. Many “boat people” were shocked to discover that they were not considered genuine refugees and would be sent back to the country they had tried to escape. This political cartoon presents a critique of screening policies which could result in forced repatriation of refugees.

This protest in a refugee camp was one of many staged throughout camps in Hong Kong, including Chimawan and Whitehead, in order to raise international awareness about the issue of forced repatriation of refugees. This protest occurred in the early 1990s. Organized into a formation that spelled out “SOS,” the protesters made a clear and symbolic call for help, asserting what little political power they had in the camps.

At age ten, Dao Vu Minh created this ink on paper artwork from his living quarters in Hong Kong’s Whitehead Detention Center: a top bunk, measuring approximately 8 x 6 x 3 feet. He left Saigon, Vietnam with his two brothers and lost contact with his parents while in the camp. Minh depicted the camp protests and riots in his art.

The sign depicted in this work reads _tha chet khong ve viet nam_, or "rather die than go back to Vietnam."

News reports from the 1980s and 1990s indicate that when riots broke out in the closed camps in Hong Kong, camp guards would spray tear gas onto the rioters. Refugees used cloth masks like these to protect themselves. Handwriting on one side of this mask reads "Freedom or Death... Whitehead detention center, Hong Kong." The other side reads "Never come back with Communists."

Trinh Do’s _Stop_ depicts the impediments to leaving the refugee camps and resettling in final asylum countries. The artist has written the names of countries with refugee camps on locks, indicating that refugees have been locked out through screening processes.

The 1989 Geneva Conference resulted in the Comprehensive Plan of Action (CPA), which included a provision for the repatriation of asylum-seekers denied refugee status. Under the CPA, these people were given the option to voluntarily return to their home countries or to ultimately face forced repatriation.

The flags on the upraised hand are the nations that accepted Vietnamese refugees, but the hand gesture and the word ‘stop’ may symbolize an action of refusal by these governments as they became overwhelmed by refugees.

While the CPA attempted to also work with the countries of origin, the great disparity in the numbers of those displaced and those resettled created major problems for the Southeast Asian governments dealing with “the refugee problem.” The United States accepted a large number of refugees, and the Statue of Liberty at the center of the painting may imply the hope of freedom in the United States for this artist.

The closed camps in Hong Kong had three-tiered bunk beds. Each tier was a small compartment (8 x 6 x 3 feet) where the refugees conducted daily activities such as eating, sleeping, worshipping, and even making art.

Originally from Hong Gai, Vietnam, Hoang Quoc Bien studied at the Hanoi Art College but stopped his studies when he was drafted into the army in 1966. He escaped Vietnam and arrived in Whitehead Detention Center, Hong Kong in 1988. He specialized in painting portraits and he also wrote poetry. By 1990, he was facing forced repatriation.

In this vibrant watercolor painting, Hoang Quoc Bien captures aspects of the living conditions of refugees. A man and woman are resting in their small cubicle-like living space, surrounded by nothing but a few personal items. Barbed wire takes a prominent place in the painting, as it cuts across the two people and all the aspects of their existence.

Chinese Vietnamese artist Nguyen Quang Phuc arrived in Hong Kong in 1988 from Hanoi, Vietnam with his wife, son, and daughter. His refugee status was refused in 1990. During his time in Whitehead Detention Center, he created many works of art that were collected by student-activists from the University of California, Irvine as part of the humanitarian organization called Project Ngoc. 

This watercolor painting invites viewers into the emotional life of refugees. Nguyen uses uncharacteristically bright colors to represent life in a refugee camp. When the geometric shapes combine, we see three figures, each experiencing their own sadness, fatigue, and exasperation regarding their situation and status.

This photograph collage prominently features children in the over-crowded and confining spaces of refugee camp life. Created by UC Irvine students involved with Project Ngoc, a humanitarian organization that advocated for Southeast Asian refugee rights, the photograph collage was part of the group’s effort to educate the campus and local community about the struggles of refugees. Project Ngoc members went on “fact-finding missions” to the Southeast Asian camps and documented the conditions, bringing back numerous photographs and artwork.

Khuu Phuoc Nguyen came to Hong Kong from Saigon, Vietnam in 1989. She found temporary shelter initially on Green Island for several months and then moved to High Island Reservoir Detention Center. Nguyen was 23 at the time she created this painting.

This watercolor illustrates how refugees are a stateless people caught “neither here nor there.” Nguyen, like many others, waited for the day when she would settle in a new country. Through light and shadow, the subdued color choices, and the imposing clock hovering over the two figures in tight quarters, the painting calls attention to a difficult life in waiting.

The time that refugees spent in transit has been described as a “limbo state” or “midway-to-nowhere” by researchers studying the Southeast Asian exodus. News coverage from the 1980s tended to highlight the deplorable conditions of refugee camps, particularly the over-crowded closed camps in Hong Kong. For many refugees, the long months or years of waiting in camps created conditions of desperation and hopelessness. At the same time, many refugees quickly took action such as creating newsletters that circulated important information to newly arrived refugee cohorts. Some created art while waiting for resettlement. Many refugees persevered each day through activities such as playing sports or learning English in preparation for their anticipated new lives.

The months or years that refugees spent in camp might have been slightly more tolerable for some with the help of art. There were art classes taught in the camps to refugees of all ages who had no prior skills, and there were also established artists who brought with them the desire to create. The Southeast Asian Archive has acquired both amateur and professional art from refugee camps as historical record of the thoughts, feelings, and visions of those who endured war and displacement.

Originally from Thanh Hoa, Vietnam, Nguyen Thi Nham studied under artist Trinh Do. She is also his wife and the couple have four children together. They left Vietnam with their ten-year-old son and arrived in Whitehead Detention Center in 1989. Women artists often did not have the same opportunities or exposure as their male counterparts to create or display their artwork. At the time this painting was created, their family was waiting for a determination on their refugee status from the Refugee Status Review Board comprised of Hong Kong representatives operating in consultation with the United Nations High Commissioner on Refugees. 

Her painting is created with ink, color, gouache, and graphite. It conjures a scene of industrious brick-making in Vietnam and offers a temporary nostalgic look at the homeland while waiting for a new life in camp.

In 1990, this report was published by the Indochina Resource Action Center (later renamed the Southeast Asia Resource Action Center) enumerating the particular conditions women and children suffered in the camps, including lack of support for pregnant and lactating women, malnutrition in women and children, and a sense of helplessness and confinement in tight quarters.

_Hy Vọng_ translates to _hope_. In at least two refugee camps, Chimawan and Nei Kwu Chau, Vietnamese refugees used “Hy Vọng” as the name of their newsletters. These newsletters included Vietnamese translations of information from international news agencies as well as poetry, fiction, and illustrations created by writers and artists inside the camps. The newsletters provided a means of expressing a sense of community and identity for refugees awaiting resettlement.

Poet Tran Da Tu pays homage to Vietnamese and European artists in this poem. He calls them “offspring of light”  who have just “walked out of the rainbow.” He suggests that through their creations, the artists give us hope.
fields.custom_metadata:
**Title:** Those who walk out of the rainbow

**Date:** December 1989

**Collection:** [Project Ngoc Records](/collections/52/)

**Contributing Institution:** [UC Irvine Libraries, Southeast Asian Archive](/institution/15/collections/)
fields.custom_title: Those who walk out of the rainbow

fields.essay:
Scholars of Southeast Asian history and culture have remarked on the important role of art in helping refugees process, express, and heal from their traumatic experiences.

In _The Invisible Citizens of Hong Kong: Art and Stories of Vietnamese Boatpeople_, Sophia Suk-mun Law writes about how art can be a language to express unspeakable pain. In “Negotiating Memories of War: Arts in Vietnamese American Communities,” Yen Le Espiritu suggests that, “As a medium that gives us a record of the culture of a period, arts can be a means of reclaiming the past by making present other memories that have been pushed to the margins.” 

Refugee artworks allow us to understand the sorrow of refugee experience with greater depth, and they show us the possibility for beauty to arise out of the destruction of war. In the after-lives of war, we recognize how tragedy and desperation can exist simultaneously with fierce strength and hope.

fields.title: Glossary
fields.essay:
**YBP:** “_Years Before Present_.” Scientists use this time scale to refer to events that happened in the past. This age scale is based on the reliable and consistent use of radiocarbon dating in the 1950s. Since time is constantly changing, YBP is counted from the year 1950.

**Ethnography:** the study and systematic recording of human cultures. Much of what we know about rock art has come from listening to the people whose ancestors created it.

**Shaman:** a person believed to communicate with the spirit world in order to divine future events or heal the sick.

fields.title: Definition: stereoscopic view
fields.essay: Stereoscopic views were a new form of entertainment in the mid-1800s. These photographs of people and places, which appeared three-dimensional when viewed, offered viewers a way to "travel" without leaving home. The technology is fairly simple: two nearly identical photos offering slightly different views of the same scene are printed next to each other on a card. When seen through a stereo viewer (a simple handheld device), they create a 3D effect.

fields.title: Glossary
fields.essay:
**Land grant:** a gift of real estate made by a government or other authority to an individual. It may be as a reward for services, or as incentives to develop undeveloped land in a relatively unpopulated country.

**Diseño:** an informal, hand-drawn map made by Californios to mark out their properties. _Diseño_ means "drawing" or "sketch" in Spanish.

**Surveyor map:** an official land map created for legal purposes and drawn by trained professionals.

**Tintype:** a positive photograph made on a sensitized sheet of enameled iron or tin.

fields.title: Definition: Manifest Destiny
fields.essay: Manifest Destiny is the historical belief that the United States was ordained by God to expand across the North American continent, from the Atlantic seaboard to the Pacific Ocean. Originally a 19th-century political catch phrase, Manifest Destiny eventually became a standard historical term. It is sometimes used as a synonym for the expansion of the United States across the North American continent which the belief inspired or was used to justify.

fields.title: Glossary
fields.essay:
**Daguerreotype:** one-of-a-kind image created on silver-plated copper. Daguerreotypes are named for their creator, the French commercial artist Louis Jacques Mande Daguerre, who discovered the process in 1837.

**Cased photograph:** a daguerreotype presented in a miniature framed case.

**Lithograph:** a print made from a drawing on a stone or metal plate. Lithographs were a popular form of newspaper illustration in the 19th century.

fields.title: About WRA photographs and Dorothea Lange
fields.essay:
The War Relocation Authority (WRA) records represent the official documentation of the evacuation, internment centers, and resettlement of Japanese Americans from 1942 to 1946. The WRA photographs and their captions are the official documentation of the WRA and reflect the point of view that the WRA wanted to present to the citizens of the United States during World War II. They present an idealistic view of the assembly centers and camps that does not reflect the sacrifices and hardships endured by the Japanese Americans.

Photographer Dorothea Lange is most famous for her Dust Bowl photographs, which showed the human face of "hard times." Although she followed the “letter of the law” in her WRA photographs, her striking images silently portray the raw emotional experience of internment. Not surprisingly, 97% of her WRA photographs (including many Calisphere images) were never published.

fields.title: Note about racial slurs
fields.essay: Some primary sources in this topic may contain racial epithets, such as "Jap," that we recognize as offensive today. The original captions from the WRA photographs, many of which were published in the Los Angeles Examiner, contain cultural references that reflect 1940s terminology. The University of California does not condone this language, but includes it in the interests of historical accuracy.

fields.title: Glossary
fields.essay:
**Assembly Centers/Detention Centers:** Temporary local housing for evacuated Japanese Americans before they were assigned to relocation camps.

**Evacuation:** The removal of Japanese Americans from their homes due to Executive Order 9066, signed in 1942 by President Roosevelt.

**Internment/Incarceration:** Between 1942 and 1945, more than 120,000 Japanese Americans were held in camps scattered throughout the West and South. Although popularly used to refer to the mass incarceration of Japanese Americans, the term internment more accurately reflects the arrest and trial of non-citizens belonging to a nation the United States was fighting during World War II. Internment procedures were largely regulated by the Geneva Convention. The term incarceration more appropriately reflects the unconstitutional removal of Japanese Americans from their homes to the camps.

**Issei (or Isei):** Literally, "first generation"; issei (ee'-sey) are Japanese who immigrated to the United States after 1907 and were not eligible or citizenship until 1952.

**Nikkei:** All peoples of Japanese ancestry in the Americas.

**Nisei:** Literally, "second generation"; nisei (nee’-sey) are the American-born children of Japanese immigrants and therefore American citizens.

**Sansei:** Literally, "third generation"; sansei (son’-sey) are the American-born grandchildren of Japanese immigrants and therefore American citizens.

**Relocation:** Used by the US government to mean being transferred to the camps.

**Relocation Camps/Internment Camps/Concentration Camps/Evacuation Centers:** Terms often used interchangeably to refer to 10 remote camps in the Western and Southern United States, where more than 120,000 Japanese American men, women, and children were incarcerated during World War II.

**Resettlement:** Term used by the US government to refer to the release of the internees and their transition and reintegration into postwar American life.

fields.title: About WRA photographs and Dorothea Lange
fields.essay:
The War Relocation Authority (WRA) records represent the official documentation of the evacuation, internment centers, and resettlement of Japanese Americans from 1942 to 1946. The WRA photographs and their captions are the official documentation of the WRA and reflect the point of view that the WRA wanted to present to the citizens of the United States during World War II. They present an idealistic view of the assembly centers and camps that does not reflect the sacrifices and hardships endured by the Japanese Americans.

Photographer Dorothea Lange is most famous for her Dust Bowl photographs, which showed the human face of "hard times." Although she followed the “letter of the law” in her WRA photographs, her striking images silently portray the raw emotional experience of internment. Not surprisingly, 97% of her WRA photographs (including many Calisphere images) were never published.

fields.title: Note about racial slurs
fields.essay: Some primary sources in this topic may contain racial epithets, such as "Jap," that we recognize as offensive today. The original captions from the WRA photographs, many of which were published in the Los Angeles Examiner, contain cultural references that reflect 1940s terminology. The University of California does not condone this language, but includes it in the interests of historical accuracy.

fields.title: Glossary
fields.essay:
**Assembly Centers/Detention Centers:** Temporary local housing for evacuated Japanese Americans before they were assigned to relocation camps.

**Evacuation:** The removal of Japanese Americans from their homes due to Executive Order 9066, signed in 1942 by President Roosevelt.

**Internment/Incarceration:** Between 1942 and 1945, more than 120,000 Japanese Americans were held in camps scattered throughout the West and South. Although popularly used to refer to the mass incarceration of Japanese Americans, the term internment more accurately reflects the arrest and trial of non-citizens belonging to a nation the United States was fighting during World War II. Internment procedures were largely regulated by the Geneva Convention. The term incarceration more appropriately reflects the unconstitutional removal of Japanese Americans from their homes to the camps.

**Issei (or Isei):** Literally, "first generation"; issei (ee'-sey) are Japanese who immigrated to the United States after 1907 and were not eligible or citizenship until 1952.

**Nikkei:** All peoples of Japanese ancestry in the Americas.

**Nisei:** Literally, "second generation"; nisei (nee’-sey) are the American-born children of Japanese immigrants and therefore American citizens.

**Sansei:** Literally, "third generation"; sansei (son’-sey) are the American-born grandchildren of Japanese immigrants and therefore American citizens.

**Relocation:** Used by the US government to mean being transferred to the camps.

**Relocation Camps/Internment Camps/Concentration Camps/Evacuation Centers:** Terms often used interchangeably to refer to 10 remote camps in the Western and Southern United States, where more than 120,000 Japanese American men, women, and children were incarcerated during World War II.

**Resettlement:** Term used by the US government to refer to the release of the internees and their transition and reintegration into postwar American life.

They present an idealistic view of the assembly centers and camps that does not reflect the sacrifices and hardships endured by the Japanese Americans.

Photographer Dorothea Lange is most famous for her Dust Bowl photographs, which showed the human face of "hard times." Although she followed the “letter of the law” in her WRA photographs, her striking images silently portray the raw emotional experience of internment. Not surprisingly, 97% of her WRA photographs (including many Calisphere images) were never published.

fields.title: Note about picture captions
fields.essay: The original captions on some of the historical photographs may include racial terms that were commonplace at the time, but considered to be derogatory today.

fields.title: Note about dates
fields.essay: Few native artifacts from pre-Columbian California have persisted into the 21st century. No original images in this topic were created before the early 19th century.

fields.title: Heading Image
fields.essay: The heading image shows Aliso Canyon, near Laguna Beach. Aliso Canyon looking toward ocean near Laguna Beach, California. Source: Edward W. Cochems Photographs

fields.title: Exhibition Images
fields.essay: The images in this exhibition can be found throughout UC Irvine's Special Collections & Archives digital collections on Calisphere, including the Artists' books collection, Edward W. Cochems Photographs, Wally Gerhardt Photographs, Hugh R. McMillan Photographs, and the Pleasants Family Papers.

fields.title: Finding Aids
fields.essay:
Please view the guides for this collection (also called finding aids) on the Online Archive of California (OAC).

Eric L. Berne Papers, 1939-1973, MSS 82-0
(This accession primarily contains photographs and reel-to-reel audiotape recordings of lectures and SFSPS meetings.)

Eric L. Berne Papers, 1931-1970, MSS 89-12
(This accession contains a significant portion of correspondence, writings, records of the ITAA, and military psychiatry records.)

Eric L. Berne Papers, 1933-1971, MSS 2003-12
(This accession primarily contains writings, notes and lectures.)

Eric L. Berne Papers, 1929-1970, MSS 2005-08
(This accession includes records of Berne's education, military service, and travels, as well as a significant amount of writings and audio recordings.)

Eric L. Berne Papers, 1963-1970, MSS 2013-18
(This accession contains 7 recorded lectures by Eric Berne and 44 audiocassettes from the International Transactional Analysis Association Tape Library.)

Eric L. Berne Papers, 1904-2007, MSS 2013-19
(This large accession includes personal correspondence, diaries, travel ephemera, educational files, writings, photographs, and artifacts.)

These collections are open for research and can be viewed in the UCSF Archives reading room. Please visit this page to make an appointment or contact an archivist: http://www.library.ucsf.edu/collections/archives/access

If needed, this section allows you to include notes regarding language in captions or definitions of terms.

fields.title: Side Panel Note 2
fields.essay: This is a second note if so desired.

fields.title: Definitions
fields.essay:
Southeast Asian

In this exhibition, "Southeast Asian" refers specifically to the populations from Cambodia, Laos, and Vietnam—countries that made up the former French Indochina and whose peoples were displaced by the Vietnam War.

Camps of first asylum

"Camps of first asylum" refers to the places where refugees initially arrived and were processed for potential resettlement.

Boat people

“Boat people” was the term used by the news media and in government and scholarly publications to refer to people who escaped their countries by boat following the Vietnam War.
